bug.author: keisukefukuda
bug.summary: ChainerMN's ImageNet example is broken because of update in pickle module
bug.description:
Conditions
Chainer >= 5.0.0
Code to reproduce The ImageNet example on Python >= 3.6
<denchmark-code>import multiprocessing p = multiprocessing.Process(target=lambda *x: x, args=()) p.start() </denchmark-code>
Error messages, stack traces, or logs
<denchmark-code>Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/process.py", line 105, in start self._popen = self._Popen(self) File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/context.py", line 223, in _Popen return _default_context.get_context().Process._Popen(process_obj) File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/context.py", line 291, in _Popen return Popen(process_obj) File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/popen_forkserver.py", line 35, in __init__ super().__init__(process_obj) File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/popen_fork.py", line 20, in __init__ self._launch(process_obj) File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/popen_forkserver.py", line 47, in _launch reduction.dump(process_obj, buf) File "/home/kfukuda/.pyenv/versions/anaconda3-4.3.1/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/reduction.py", line 60, in dump ForkingPickler(file, protocol).dump(obj) _pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <function <lambda> at 0x7fb633f35e18>: attribute lookup <lambda> on __main__ failed </denchmark-code>
For details, see <denchmark-link:https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/pickle.html>https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/pickle.html</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-code>The following types can be pickled:
* None, True, and False * integers, floating point numbers, complex numbers * strings, bytes, bytearrays * tuples, lists, sets, and dictionaries containing only picklable objects * functions defined at the top level of a module (using def, not lambda) * built-in functions defined at the top level of a module * classes that are defined at the top level of a module * instances of such classes whose __dict__ or the result of calling __getstate__() is picklable (see section Pickling Class Instances for details). </denchmark-code>
Thus lambda is not pickable.
